1578268512_16Fw7LqBDEgoFYTkiJBsywYJRtoRR.body:
I have 2 aspects to it. First of all, the Edward Snowden's behaviour is as American as it gets. The shoddy escape planning, the sincere belief that if the ills of the Government are revealed to the public, then things will be OK and fixed, the sincere American patriotism of accepting the risks just in the name of doing the Right Thing for the America. In my view, he is certainly a hero, but unfortunately slightly stupid, naive hero. Was it worth it? Not the way he expected it to be, but in an unexpected way HUGELY WORTH IT. The way he was treated by the U.S. government and the various European governments PROOVED that in reality in the 21. century there is no way to tell publicly about the ill-doings of the Western governments without being the target of repressions. With China, Russia, Arab states that's kind of granted, but the fact that it also holds for the Western governments, not just the U.S., was TOTALLY NEW INFORMATION and interestingly I haven't read or heard the Edward Snowden itself ever talking about that aspect of his case. He just talks/writes about the revelations and mass surveillance, but the mass surveillance part is kind of irrelevant in a sense that the 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECHELON
was public knowledge long before his revelations became public and already in year 2003 or so we (as students) were told at our cryptography lecture that a good way to design software is to apply encryption whenever possible, because if there is an opportunity for some party to abuse the situation, it will get eventually abused. So, from that point of view, the existence of the mass surveillance project does not really change anything, because, well, if the software developers did their job properly, the agencies may try what they may, they would just not succeed. The key lengths, strengths of crypto algorithms can also be bumped up with some spare strength without knowing almost anything about the surveillance projects, because the minimum feature size of digital logic microchips and therefore their maximum computational power is public knowledge. It's obvious that the agencies have the money to create their own custom crypto breaking chips, so the key sizes that are not reachable for the agencies are kind of calculable without any leaks.

And what has really changed after the revelations? From software development point of view, pretty much nothing. Software developers and hardware developers still rely on standard crypto libraries that have some standard key lengths and  standard algorithms that can be broken by the agencies and that is a Good Case. Often times the developers think just about features, not security, and the end users also pay just for features, not security. The sales people can always lie about the security of the products and hardly anybody audits, whether there is any truth there, specially, if the products use some "standard and publicly approved" crypto chips or crypto algorithms. People want the IoT appliances to run as long as possible from a single set of batteries or from a single charge and in general the case tends to be that the stronger the crypto, the more calculations need to be done, but the more calculations need to be done, the more current/power the IoT device consumes and the bigger the power consumption, the faster the battery empties, so the security wise crappier IoT device manufacturer wins the race with their argument that their device can work longer with a single charge or single set of batteries. Or how many "ordinary people" encrypt their plain email? Has the number of GMail users or Facebook users declined because of the Snowden revelations? I guess not.

The major change that the Edward Snowden case brought to the world was the knowledge that the advertised Western Values of treating crime reporting parties well REALLY DO NOT HOLD. If we add the Bradley_Manning/Chelsea_Manning case to the mix, then we get clear cover-ups of blatant murder by the U.S. government
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/July_12,_2007,_Baghdad_airstrike
The way the Snowden and the Manning were treated clearly sent the Western Values DOWN THE TUBES in a GRAND SCALE. Even if the Edward Snowden is/were a Russian spy, his bad treatment by the U.S. government is a TOTAL INTELLIGENCE FAILURE IN A GRAND SCALE, because it allowed the Russian and Chinese intellectual top brass, the future Russian and Chinese top engineers, to see that there is no point of emigrating from the Russia or China to the West, because value wise people, who report horrible corruption and wrongdoings, literally murders by the government, get really bad treatment there, but at the same time the Russian and Chinese top universities are "for free" while the western engineering salaries barely cover the university tuition fees of the children of the engineers. Russian top universities and Chinese top universities are certainly not worse than the "average" Western top universities, at least what regards to the skills that people acquire there. The Pentagon can be pretty sure that the graduates of Russian universities and Chinese universities are able to design such weapons to Russia and China that are able to properly challenge the West. Those BRIGHTEST hearts and minds were alienated with the bad treatment of the Edward Snowden and the Bradley/Chelsea Manning. It is exactly THOSE YOUNG PEOPLE and also the current Russian and Chinese engineers and scientists that will notice things and that will DETERMINE THE ARMS RACE, not the average Facebook users that will continue uploading everything to the Facebook even after the Edward Snowden revelations. From that point of view even if the CIA/FBI/whoever-else suspected or knew the Edward Snowden to be a Russian spy, they should have made sure that he gets a really good, non-repressive, treatment, because the current solution is AN ABSOLUTE FAILURE FROM PSYCHOLOGICAL OPERATIONS POINT OF VIEW and from the point of view of WINNING HEARTS AND MINDS OF THE INTELLECTUALLY BRIGHTEST Russians and Chinese. Intelligence agencies always need "assets", spies on the other side. Often times the best "traitors" at the other side are "traitors" due to ideological reasons, like the ones spying for the Soviet Union disliked how people were treated in the capitalist society and the ones spying for the U.S. side disliked, how the Soviet regime treated the soviet people. The CIA very likely LOST many future "traitors" in Russia and China due to the way the Edward Snowden and the Bradley/Chelsea Manning were treated. I emphasize, it is not the "average" person, who determines, what will happen in the world in the grand scale. It is always the brightest people that determine the outcomes. Even the Donald Trump, as stupid as he is at very many things, is actually quite bright in real-estate business and reality-shows, because there are plenty of people, who inherit great wealth from their parents, but only few are capable of achieving the brand, for better and for worse, that the Donald Trump has been able to achieve during his lifetime. It would have been easy for him to just take the inheritance, do drugs, be an "investor", live off of some rental income and not bother with any of the real estate business or reality show business, but, bastard or not, he certainly worked hard on his business projects, regardless of whether they are ethically questionable and in debt or not. That is to say, in a narrow context even the Donald Trump is actually a very bright guy. Horrible at very many things, not necessarily a nice guy either, but a bright guy at a narrow context. Even if his presidential campaign was just another effort to promote his hotel chain business, he certainly succeeded and the various diplomats book a room at the Washington horribly overpriced TRUMP hotel just to please him. Again, not nice, but a success. 

The summary is that regardless of whether the Edward Snowden is/was a Russian spy or not, the mistreatment of him by the Western government is a TOTAL INTELLIGENCE FAILURE in terms of loosing the hearts and minds of the people, who now will start working for the Russian weapons programs and Chinese weapons programs in stead of emigrating to the West, specially given the cost of living in the U.S. if the cost of the children university tuition fees and healthcare fees are added to the list of expenses. The purpose of the CIA and other Western intelligence agencies is to PREVENT the enemies of the U.S. from developing good weapons, not to facilitate the creation of a new Cold War style arms race. The Western European governments also totally failed by not offering the Edward Snowden asylum, specially the Germany. And nobody, not even the Edward Snowden itself, talks about that SERIOUS FAILURE of the western intelligence agencies.

Have a nice day.

1580594957_1AEx7ASy4xvEkpjJKweTVD2hnsKmP.body:
https://www.vim.org/

Has a high learning curve, but all major IDEs at least partly support Vi/Vim key bindings, even the Microsoft Visual Studio. Sometimes the IDEs need a plugin for the Vi/Vim key bindings support. The key bindings should be learned like words of a foreign language: one key binding per day combined with repetition/use of the bindings from previous days. Before starting to learn the Vim key bindings, one should be able to type without watching the keyboard and that can be learned in about 2 weeks, about 2h of practicing per day, provided that the training tool is right. Here's one really good training tool:

http://www.doorwayonline.org.uk/typing/

Please note that the sound part is an important element of the typing training, so please make sure that You have headphones or otherwise have switched in the sound. The main benefit of being able to type without watching the keyboard is the ability to use a much more ergonomic working position and the ability to keep one's attention on the content of the writable text in stead of being distracted by the physical activity of entering the text. Imagine, how hard it would be to write with a plain pen, if in stead of thinking about what to write, the thoughts are distracted by the effort of using the pen. The same applies to using a keyboard: it helps a lot, if one can just think one's thoughts in stead of being distracted by the effort of entering text. The Vim key bindings just reduce the amount of keystrokes that one has to make, when coding/programming. An alternative to the Vim is the 

https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/

but the Emacs key bindings do not reduce the number of keystrokes as much as the Vim key bindings do. May be it could be said that the Emacs is more "verbose" than Vim, but the succinctness of the Vim does come with the price of a pretty high learning curve. Expect it to take about a year to learn most of the Vim key bindings after You already master the typing without watching the keyboard.

 Thank You for reading this comment.

1581100642_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
The ZeroNet is not for real-time communication. The architecture of the ZeroNet is that signed copies of files are shared and if a ZeroNet site, generally called as zite, has a newer version, let's say, the original author of a zite adds another entry to its blog, then a newer signed version of the file(s) get(s) distributed around. Forums like the current one contain multiple posts, which are signed files. It is possible to distribute sound files like OGG, MP3, WAV, etc. but the classical streaming is not possible. For real-time communication the Tor network should be used. You may also study the 
https://matrix.org/

> [mrsex](#comment_1_158mjMWcgfLDnSd8Q7kEivftCtr3hA2aj4): i am a chinese ,a new user i hear that here can safe from gov's control.

Welcome, but please be aware that the ZeroNet offers only the possibility to publish without the possibility of censors to take down information, but to get anonymity, the ZeroNet has to be tunneled through Tor. On the other hand, the middle ground that does NOT provide anonymity, but alleviates the situation, is to switch in encryption. The ZeroNet python start-up script console parameter is "--force_encryption", like

    python2 ./zeronet.py --force_encryption

The Great FireWall of China will probably block all Tor traffic, so that's an issue, but You might try to create a VPN-connection to some Western server, for example, Your own rented VPS (Virtual Private Server). You may try to tunnel Your traffic through an SSH tunnel. If that works, then You might be able to still use the Tor.

1582025950_12zcNM3BD6QwkonPrnCdbWBnGzu9b.body:
How about the reason that there is no other WORLD WIDE network available that I can afford. The ZeroNet and Tor also depend on the censored internet, the IPv4 network. What regards to the lack of reliability, then the plain internet connection from my local Internet Service Provider is currently the best that I've got. I do point out that the IPv4 network started to get used by re-using existing network hardware, which was the telephone network. There were such devices called MODEM-s. A MODEM stands for Modulator-DeModulator. A phone line MODEM was a device that was in the role of a network card and it could be an external device that connected to the computer over the parallel port, the same old port that was used for connecting printers.

On the other hand, some of the very old, telephone line based, "bulleting board" systems function even today. I do not know all of them, but FidoNet is one of them.

https://www.fidonet.org/
http://filegate.net/
http://ftsc.org/

The classical one, the one, where the Linus Torvalds announced the Linux, was USENET and since text transmission was supported, binary files like images were first converted to text.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Base64
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uuencoding
http://parchive.sourceforge.net/

There are some alternative grassroots network hardware projects, but they are not covering the whole planet. A partial list of them:
https://guifi.net/
https://wirelessleiden.nl/
https://www.funkfeuer.at/
https://freifunk.net/
http://servalproject.org/

What regards to the routing protocols, then here are a few more prominent ones:
http://www.olsr.org/
https://www.open-mesh.org/

You may want to look at the following video for introduction:
"[DEFCON 20] Off-Grid Communications with Android: Meshing the Mobile World"
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kl5sMPXs3cI

You may think of the routing task as finding a path in a city, from one house to another. There can be multiple paths and the paths can be the same regardless of how the house "addresses" are written down. In The West houses are "addressed" by street name and house number, but in Japan houses are "addressed" differently, mainly by "house number within a batch of houses".
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_addressing_system
Just like a route from one house to another can differ, depending on whether one uses a truck, a small car or a bike, the routing in a mesh network can also depend on the capabilities of the devices. Small volume of low-speed communication might be routed from one small microcontroller device to another, but a video is another matter. What is certain, is that devices join and leave the network at any time, so a static map does not make sense, and there are so many devices on planet Earth, in the future also on other planets, that it is not possible for a device to include a "world map" of devices. The old, nicely static, IPv4 and IPv6 systems were developed for a situation, where the adversary can only nuke or bomb a facility or raid at most some of the facilities, not all of the facilities at once. An "underground" mesh network has a far more difficult task to solve.

> [bubbleghost](#comment_1_1GbAD8KRx8aHKRE4PZs8pT4xPVLUfrGMRc): Lots of foreigners now in IT. We need the good ol' days back.

What would those old days look like? The way I distinguish myself from Indian cheap labor is quality. My definition of quality is not what everybody considers appropriate. For example, I have noticed that Americans do NOT care about reliability and Japanese, do care about reliability, but only, if the solution is very old and tested out during some very long time period. Consequently it is impossible to sell something novel to the Japanese, because anything novel is by definition NEW, NOT OLD, and it is impossible to sell anything reliable to the impatient Americans, because if the reliability is not important, then why should they pay for the laborious proper solution, if they can just pick some cheap and crappy service from India or God-knows-where? Besides, the crappier the job, the less time it takes to do it and Americans tend to prefer fast delivery to proper deliverables. On the other hand, there is one niche, where quality seems to be always important regardless of cultural background: science, research. Scientists, including the ones at the private laboratories, do not tolerate software that calculates things wrongly. Those intelligent people are also a joy to serve. They are demanding, but their high demands also keeps my competition at bay, so good for me! Add the fact that scientists can burn through a lot of money and some of them are always almost broke, and I even have a price advantage, because the big software development companies charge much more than I do.

Another interesting modern niche that seems to be emerging, is the various embedded devices, which all need some kind of desktop/mobile/server software nowadays. A company that does a bad job at that will bear heavy monetary  losses, so quality will be a nice barrier against the cheap crap-writers from India. Those devices also need firmware, the software that goes into the microcontrollers. Printers, watches, toys, wall-clocks, microwave ovens, even plain electric drills contain firmware nowadays. An electric drill operates by using a large field transistor that operates a Pulse-With-Modulation mode, meaning, it switches on and off very rapidly, at least thousands of times per second, and the drill speed is determined by the percentage that the transistor is in the on-state. It is firmware, software running in a microcontroller, that measures the drill trigger position and then switches the field-transistor on and off according to the  drill trigger position. That is to say, with the emergence of the various IoT and with the lowering of the electronics prices in general, the need for firmware developers should increase, because almost everything has some firmware in it. You might not believe it, but even ordinary USB-memory-sticks and memory-cards have a microcontroller in them that implements wear-leveling, error correction, etc. Often times the firmware for that microcontroller has been loaded to the chip at the factory or the chip might have it designed in as a mask level ROM(read-only-memory). There are a lot of opportunities, but those opportunities are not for amateurs, for some average Joe that learned to program a year before applying for the job. Obviously most of those opportunities are NOT at the big corporate world, but for freelancers. Social people, who yearn for corporate life, will not enjoy those jobs, unless they rent a desk at some co-working space. 
 But, for those, who want to work hard as freelancers, opportunities do exist.

The best option for an alternative news feed is to create one for Yourself from blogs of different academics. The YaCy is a great idea, but my tests over years show that its implementation is such that it keeps a lot of data in RAM and once the RAM runs out, it crashes. It's designed for huge servers with 10-s of GiB of RAM to spare, not laptops or desktop computers. Basically, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE YACY IS CRAP AND SEEMS TO HAVE BEEN CRAP FROM THE VERY START! But the ideas there are good, just that good ideas without a proper implementation are almost worthless. Also, when someone thinks of implementing their own P2P search engine, then please take to account the fact that there will be malicious nodes on the P2P-network and not that many people are willing to spend money on hosting  other people's data.

"The Economics of Censorship Resistance"
https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/Papers/redblue.pdf

On top of that HDD/SSD traffic is a bottle-neck for all P2P-systems, meaning, the end user experience suffers unless the P2P-applications like Freenet and ZeroNet and so forth are running on a dedicated machine, not the machine that the end user uses as a workstation. Not that many people are willing to keep their old computers running to host P2P-applications and those, who do, can not run a sloppily Frankenstein-ed beast like the YaCy on those machines.

Tor is just an overlay network, a protocol that depends on the IPv4/IPv6. If there is no IPv4 and no IPv6 network in place, Tor will become useless. In theory after the sea cables are cut between continents, satellite phones and satellite phone based IPv4 connections might still work, but given the price of such connections it is unlikely that someone is willing to pay for it just to let some guy stream YouTube music over it. Operators of various chat systems like the 
https://telegram.org/
or some hactivists running
https://bitmessage.org/
might use their own custom software to convey only some of the traffic of those chat applications over their own financed satellite links and may be at some point some messages might be transmitted from the Western side to extra censored areas by using the
https://othernet.is/
and then there is also the option of radio amateur relay stations, but it is a very low-volume traffic and it requires special software at the service operator side. All-in-all, forget Tor in those scenarios, but You may build Your own link, at Your own expense, to transfer some small-olume ZeroNet or 
https://beakerbrowser.com/
pages from one region to another and help to keep information spreading that way. The ultra-rich in China are probably using western satellite telephones and their modems for daily business operations anyway, as do probably Russian oligarchs and the various Arab business people. If You're working on some university cube-sat project, then You might want to create Your own relay satellite that picks data up at one side of the globe and dispatches it at the other side of the globe. It would make an awesome ZeroNet zite distribution link. The Chinese and Russians and alike have the capability to shoot down satellites, but they try to do it with a laser, so You may want to design some mirrors to protect the side that points to Earth. The other side is for solar panels. Make sure that the mirrors disperse the beam so that You won't inadvertently hit a passenger plane or someone on the ground with the high intensity reflected beam. The dispersing of the beam makes Your satellite easily visible, but it's visible anyway due to the downlink signal. May be a huge "satellite dish" can be 2 in one: a dispersing mirror that protects the satellite and a reflector for the directed antenna. The frequencies of the shooting laser and the radio waves differ and that difference might be leveraged.

In samurai era Japan the "ladies first" rule was used with a purpose of getting an early warning about enemy samurais in the room. A lady enters the room first, screams, when seeing enemies or just dies, if the enemies chop the lady with a sword first, but that gives the men the small time delay that is needed for drawing their own swords. The same with the Japanese politeness gesture of serving food to the guests first. The idea that if the food is poisoned with something fast-acting, then the guests are in the role of an early warning by having the symptoms, dying.
